page.title: 03SEVERN STOKE_MODERN HISTORY
page.content: { Stoke House}was built by the Earl of Coventry on the hill overlooking Severn Stoke. It was rented by the local Squire, who was employed to watch over the village and to look after the Lord's financial interests. Later, this house was bought by a rich Ceylon tea plantation owner and sold by his widow, along with the large gardens, to a developer who demolished it and built Stoke Avenue. The{old {lodge house}can still be seen on the roadside, and many of the old trees from the gardens can still be seen in amongst the new estate. In 1910 there was a{wharf}on the banks of the Severn near the village, which was used to offload supplies of coal and hay in the days of River transport.
